thread.title: Dow rises 300 points amid Draghi, earnings; McDonald's up 7.5%
thread.title_full: Dow rises 300 points amid Draghi, earnings; McDonald's up 7.5% - Yahoo Finance

author: Fred Imbert
title: Dow rises 300 points amid Draghi, earnings; McDonald's up 7.5%
text:
U.S. stocks traded sharply higher on Thursday, as Wall Street digested the European Central Bank 's rates decision, economic data and a fresh batch of earnings. 
"We were hoping the ECB would remain open to further easing, and it appears as though they are," said Art Hogan, chief market strategist at Wunderlich Securities. 
The ECB kept interest rates unchanged.
"Short-term inflation expectations have declined but more medium- to long-term inflation expectations, after some decline following our last meeting have now recovered and are basically unchanged since then," ECB President Mario Draghi said in a news conference.
Read More ECB leaves rates unchanged, all eyes on QE 

Draghi's remarks pushed the euro (Exchange:EUR=) down more than 1.5 percent against the dollar. 
Euro/dollar intraday View photo
. Source: FactSet 
"Obviously, Europe needs to devalue its currency a bit more," said Randy Frederick, managing director of trading and derivatives at Charles Schwab. "The concern of the euro gaining value is [weighing], so I think Mario Draghi is sort of trying to push that in the other direction." 
Frederick also said he expects the ECB to go further into its quantitative easing program — which began in March — before the year ends.
U.S. stocks began Thursday trading sharply higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average opening up more than 100 points before gaining 300 points.
The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite gained more than 1.5 percent after opening sharply higher.
Draghi's comments also sent European equities higher, with the German DAX and the French CAC 40 both closing above 2 percent.
"I think the markets are telling you the correction is over," said Maris Ogg, president at Tower Bridge Advisors. "If you look at these mediocre earnings, the market is taking them in stride."
Dow components McDonald's ( MCD ) , 3M ( MMM ) and Caterpillar ( CAT ) all reported before the bell. 
"So far, earnings this morning have been mixed ... but we have a lot of big names to get through still," said Peter Cardillo, chief market economist at Rockwell Global Capital. 
Read More Caterpillar CEO: Big misses reflect 'rough patch' 

McDonald's posted earnings per share and revenue that beat expectations, sending the stock up about 7 percent, and accounting for about 50 points of the Dow's gains. 
3M reported mixed earnings, while Caterpillar missed on both lines. 
Companies scheduled to report after the bell include Amazon.com ( AMZN ) , Alphabet ( GOOGL ) and Microsoft ( MSFT ) .
On the data front, investors digested weekly jobless claims and the Chicago Fed National Activity index. 
"The jobless claims number was phenomenal," Frederick said.

Read More The big costs behind Google's moonshot start-ups 

Weekly jobless claims came in at 259,000, below the expected 265,000. The September Chicago Fed national activity index came in at -0.37, slightly higher than the -0.39 August reading. 
The FHFA House Price index rose 0.3 percent in August. 
Other economic data points included September existing home sales, which rose 4.7 percent to 5.55 million. 
"That's good news," Hogan said. "We're just starting to recover from the financial crisis and housing is a very important part of the U.S. economy."

Leading indicators also fell 0.2 percent. 
Read More Investors betting record amounts against stocks 

"What this shows me is further loss of momentum in the U.S. economy," said Marie Schofield, chief economist and senior portfolio management at Columbia Management. 
Investors also kept an eye on oil prices, as U.S. crude were on pace to shed over 3 percent for the week. 
"Any kind of balance in WTI holding around $45 per barrel will be positive," Hogan said. 
U.S. oil (New York Mercantile Exchange: @CL.1) rose about 0.31 percent to $45.32 a barrel. 
Overnight , Asian stock markets closed mixed, as the Shanghai Composite rose 1.47 percent, while the Nikkei 225 fell 0.64 percent. 
In corporate news, CIT Group said CEO John Thain will retire in March, and will be replaced by Ellen Alemany, a long-time banking executive. 
Read More Treasury postpones 2-year auction on debt ceiling fears 

Lululemon ( LULU ) Chief Product Officer Tara Poseley is leaving the company after two years. 
The Dow Jones industrial average (Dow Jones Global Indexes: .DJI) rose 296 points, or 1.72 percent, with McDonald's leading advancers and American Express ( AXP ) the greatest laggard.
The S&P 500 ( ^GSPC ) rose 33 points, or 1.67 percent, at 2,052, with industrials leading nine sectors higher and health care lagging. 
The Nasdaq ( ^IXIC ) gained 77 points, or 1.6 percent, at 4,917. 

The CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) , ( ^VIX ) widely considered the best gauge of fear in the market, traded above 14.

U.S. 10-year yields traded at 2.02 percent, while two-year yields fell to 0.6. 
Advancers led decliners 5 to 1 at the New York Stock Exchange, with an exchange volume of 465 million and a composite volume of 2.187 billion as of 12:57 p.m. ET. 
Gold futures traded up 10 cents at $1,167.20 an ounce. 
On tap this week: 

Thursday 

Earnings: Amazon.com , Alphabet (Google) , Microsoft , AT&T , Juniper Networks , Pandora , Capital One , Stryker 
Friday 

9:45 a.m.: Manufacturing PMI 

Earnings: Procter and Gamble , American Airlines , Autoliv , Cabot Oil and Gas , State Street , LM Ericsson , Tenneco , Lear , Citizens Financial , VF Corp. 
More From CNBC.com: 
China will call crude oil's next move: Traders Cramer: Scariest decline I've seen in 35 years Fresh & Easy begins closing down stores —CNBC's Peter Schacknow contributed to this report.
